CatDescriptText: Myrtle Azeem, University of Pittsburgh employee, 515 Rosedale Street, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 15, 1959, pg. B1 with question: "Do you believe judges give society proper protection by refusing to send confessed murderers, guilty of murder in the first degree, to the electric chair?" answer reads: "I can think of quite a few who should have gone to the electric chair, so, therefore, I don't think that the judges, in these instances, have given us proper protection. And I think that society beenfits [sic] from electrocution because they have eliminated a maniac who should have been away years before."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Myrtle Azeem wearing light colored sleeveless blouse, square wristwatch, and striped skirt, standing in front of Jenkins Arcade with "Sitterley Co....Haberdashers" sign, Liberty Avenue, Downtown
